Now, imagine if that kind of positive feedback happened 40,000 times a year for ten years. You can see how it made a difference. Each time a young person was recognized for doing something good, they got more motivated to keep it up. Eventually, doing good just felt natural and easy.

When we want to create big change, we often think we need to start with something huge. Like the executive who made a big deal about building an elaborate dollhouse for his daughters but then ditched the project because it felt too overwhelming. Research shows that the best motivator for people is progress. Why? Because even a small win builds momentum and boosts our belief in future success. In a famous 1968 Harvard Business Review article, Frederick Herzberg found that the two main motivators for people are achievement and being recognized for it.

More recently, Teresa Amabile and Steven Kramer collected diary entries from tons of people over thousands of workdays. They discovered that â€œeveryday progressâ€”even a small winâ€ can totally change how people feel and perform.
